title": "Home-made butter and buttermilk recipe",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Home-made butter and buttermilk, a British recipe\n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#butter #buttermilk #homemadebutterandbuttermilkrecipe #doublecream #hand #salted #sodabreadrecipe #bread #thermomixbutter #breadrecipe #dough \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=Most people want buttermilk for a bread recipe\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 3206\n|PortionCalories = 13\n|DatePublished=13th November 2013\n|Author=Chef\n|ImageComment = [[Buttermilk]] and [[butter]]\n|Servings = 230 ml buttermilk / 225 g butter\n|Difficulty = 2\n|TotalTime = 12 minutes\n|PrepTime = 12 minutes\n|CookTime = None\n|Image = [[Image:Butter and buttermilk.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">It works, but worth doing?</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">3.5</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">Not sure that buying buttermilk might not be easier and simpler.  If you want to experiment though, this is how to do it.</span> \n\n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:PSmith|Paul&nbsp;R&nbsp;Smith]] </span></span>\n}}\nMost people want buttermilk for a [[bread recipe]].  This neat idea gets you not only the buttermilk, but alos the butter to spread on the bread once it's made.  All you need is 700 ml of double cream (heavy cream) and a hand whisk.\n\nOnce you over-beat the [[Double cream|double cream]], the [[Butter|butter]] begins to separate into [[Buttermilk|buttermilk]] and butter.\n\nThis can be done by [[Hand|hand]] if you have the time and the energy.  ''tip''; Have an electric whisk to hand for when you give up !\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 700 ml [[Double cream|double cream]]\n| &#188; to &#189; a teaspoon of fine [[Salt|salt]], optional for salted butter\n}}\n\n===Method===\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Pour the [[Double cream|double cream]] into a large bowl\n| Start by using the beating attachment and whisk until the [[Cream|cream]] starts to solidify - this took about 3 minutes of continual whisking.\n\n| Once the [[Butter|butter]] starts to appear, I found it easier to continue with the dough-hook attachment as butter starts to clog the whisk.\n| To prevent covering the kitchen in [[Buttermilk|buttermilk]] it's probably a good idea to decant the buttermilk you have at this stage to another container.\n| Another few minutes with the [[Dough|dough]] hook and the separation should be complete.\n| Strain off the remaining [[Buttermilk|buttermilk]], whisk in a &#188; to &#189; a teaspoon of fine [[Salt|salt]] if you want [[Salted|salted]] [[Butter|butter]].\n| On a cool day you can pat the [[Butter|butter]] into shape.  If it's very warm you can do this by [[Hand|hand]] in a bowl aof very cold water.\n| Use your [[Buttermilk|buttermilk]] to make the [[Bread|bread]] and the [[Butter|butter]] to spread on it\n}}\n<gallery widths=300px heights=300px perrow=5>\nImage:Home-made butter and buttermilk recipe_ingredients.jpg|thumb|300px|right| Beginning to separate\nImage:Home-made butter and buttermilk recipe_by_hand.jpg|thumb|300px|right|700 ml of double cream and a hand whisk\n</gallery>\n===Chef's notes===\nThis is probably a long-winded method of making butter, but it's very nice butter and quite fun, if not a little messy.  Let me know if you manage to beat it all by hand!\n==See also==\n* Our [[:Category:Bread and baking|bread and baking category]]\n* [[Soda bread recipe]]\n* [[Thermomix butter]]\n* [[Thermomix butter - Spanish recipe (TM)]]\n* [http://www.channel4.com/4food/recipes/tv-show-recipes/the-fabulous-baker-brothers-recipes/homemade-butter-recipe The fabulous Baker brothers butter recipe]\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes]]\n[[Category:British recipes]]\n[[Category:Bread and baking]]\n[[Category:Historic recipes]]\n[[Category:Marinades dressings and butters]]\n[[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]\n[[Category:Breadmaker recipes]]\n\n[[Category:Uncooked]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#butter #buttermilk #homemadebutterandbuttermilkrecipe #doublecream #hand #salted #sodabreadrecipe #bread #thermomixbutter #breadrecipe #dough </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }
    }
}

title": "Home-made Caerphilly cheese",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Home-made Caerphilly cheese a cheese recipe\n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#homemadecaerphillycheese #dvi #caerphillycheese #curds #drysalting #cheesemaking #cheese #doubleboiler #liquidstarter #curd #litres \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=Caerphilly cheese is a semi-hard cheese that originates from Caerphilly, Wales. It is a fast-ripening, acidic tasting cheese\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{Template:AdvancePreparationIcon}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 2501\n|PortionCalories = 100\n|DatePublished=2nd January 2013\n|Author=Chef\n|Servings = Servings: 25 - Makes 750 g Caerphilly cheese\n |Difficulty = 3\n |ImageComment = Nice, respectable homemade Caerphilly cheese and the well-nibbled, improvised version!\n |TotalTime = 4 hours\n |PrepTime = 4 hours plus maturation period\n |CookTime = None\n|Image = [[Image:Home-made Caerphilly cheese recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">I remember making this</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">4.6</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">I kept nibbling at it as it was maturing, just to test it, you understands. :D</span> \n\n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:PSmith|Paul&nbsp;R&nbsp;Smith]] </span></span>\n}}\n[[Caerphilly cheese]] is a semi-hard [[Cheese|cheese]] that originates from Caerphilly, Wales.  It is a fast-ripening, acidic tasting cheese. The cheese is especially good if made from [[Ewes' milk|ewes' milk]].\n\nWell, I can't resist meddling, so although this started as [[Caerphilly cheese]], it may end up as something completely different as I have also added 300 ml of [[double cream]] to the [[milk]].\n\nAs I update these notes, the cheese is only 6 days old and more than half of it has been eaten!  It is absolutely delicious and everyone who has tasted, nibbled, devoured it, thought it wonderful.  It has an acidic tang with a really creamy after-taste.  An absolute success.  Making more today to see if I can get a batch to reach maturing age before being eaten.\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 5 [[Litres|litres]], full [[Fat|fat]] [[Milk|milk]]\n| 5 ml [[liquid starter]] or a little [[DVI]] (an aspirin sized heap)\n| 1.5 ml [[Rennet|rennet]]\n| [[Salt]] for  [[Dry salting]]:\n|*[[Dry salting]], 1.5% per weight of [[Curd|curd]] (15g to 1 kg of curd)\n| [[Brine concentrate]]: 18% (180 ml [[Salt|salt]] [12 level tablespoons]  per 1 litre of water)\n}}\n\n===[[Mise en place]]===\n* [[Sterilise]] all equipment\n<gallery widths=300px heights=300px perrow=5>\nImage:Home-made Caerphilly cheese pressing.jpg|Lightly pressing (3 kg)\nImage:Home-made Caerphilly cheese salting.jpg|Dry-salting the small pieces\nImage:Home-made Caerphilly cheese draining.jpg|Draining the curds\nImage:Curd draining.jpg|Press the sieve down and drain with a ladle\n</gallery>\n===Method===\n\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Pasteurise the [[Milk|milk]] in a [[Double boiler|double boiler]] and leave to cool to 30\u00b0 C.\n| Add the [[liquid starter]] or sprinkle om the [[DVI]] and leave for 30 minutes.\n| Dilute the [[Rennet|rennet]] in 5ml of cold [[Boiled|boiled]] water and add to the [[Milk|milk]].\n| Mix well.\n| Leave until the [[Curd|curd]] sets. This should take about an hour or so but may take longer.\n| Once set, [[Cut the curds|cut the curds]] into 6mm cubes and leave for 15 minutes, gently agitating the pan now and then.\n| Very gently, over a 30 minute period, increase the temperature to 34\u00b0.  I find the most reliable way to do this is by adding a little [[Boiling|boiling]] water to the water already in the [[Double boiler|double boiler]].  This prevents you raising the temperature too quickly.\n| Using a ladle, drain off as much [[whey]] as you can without further breaking up the [[curds]]. Try to keep the temperature at 34\u00b0 (covering with a cloth or working in a warm environment helps here). {Just discovered a really neat way to speed up the curd draining.  Rather than fiddle about with a ladle at the edge of the pan, press down gently with a sieve and ladle the whey from the middle of the sieve. ''See picture''.}\n| After 30 minutes, remove blocks of curds and pile them in a heap onto a [[cheesecloth]] placed over a [[cheese draining mat]].  A (very clean) fish-slice is good for this.\n| After 20 minutes, break the [[Curds|curds]] into much smaller pieces and [[dry-salt]] them (2%).\n| Lift the cheesecloth and place into your mould. I used a [[Colander|colander]].\n| Wrap and cover and lightly press (I used about 3 kg of weight).\n| After 1 hour, turn the cheese over and sprinkle with salt.  Leave it pressing for 24 hours.\n| The next day, make up an 18% [[Brine|brine]] solution and immerse the [[Cheese|cheese]] for 24 hours.\n| Allow to dry and allow 2 weeks to ripen.\n| Unless you have a cave handy, the [[fridge]] is probably the best place to mature your [[homemade cheese]] although it's really going to be too cold. After discovering the top shelf of my often-opened fridge could be as much as 5\u00b0 C warmer than the bottom, I've decided to mature my cheeses there.  As all fridges differ, check various areas of your fridge with a thermometer to find the area that is around 11\u00b0C [51\u00b0 F], the ideal 'cave' temperature.\n}}\n===Chef's note===\nMost [[cheesemaking]] recipes I have seen mention [[Pasteurisation|pasteurising]] the milk first.  This assumes you have unpasteurised milk which, though better for [[cheesemaking]], can be difficult to obtain unless you have your own dairy. If like me, you are using shop-bought, pasteurised [[milk]], ignore the pasteurising step.  Just start with the milk at 30\u00b0 C.\n\nIf you are using cream, add it with the milk after the pasteurising step (assuming it is already pasteurised). I used double cream, which gives it a really creamy after-taste but single cream would be just as good.  The amount of milk is not overly important either as long as your draining system and mould is large enough.\n\nThe recipes I have seen suggest rubbing the cheese with flour to 'finish' it.   I am uncertain about this as I feel it's likely to form an undesirable mould, as bread does.  I would welcome comments on this.\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes|Caerphilly]]\n[[Category:Cheese recipes|Caerphilly]]\n[[Category:Cheese making|Caerphilly]]\n[[Category:British recipes|Caerphilly]]\n[[Category:Historic recipes|Caerphilly]]\n[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Caerphilly]]\n[[Category:Unusual recipes]]\n[[Category:Uncooked]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#homemadecaerphillycheese #dvi #caerphillycheese #curds #drysalting #cheesemaking #cheese #doubleboiler #liquidstarter #curd #litres </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }
    }
}

title": "Home-made Cheddar cheese",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Home-made Cheddar cheese a cheese recipe \n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#curds #cheesecloth #cheese #homemadecheddarcheese #cheesemould #doubleboiler #curd #cheddar #flour #dvistarter #cutthecurds \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=This turned out to be quite successful homemade cheese recipe, though it was eaten before it matured properly! Use a double-boiler or you will scald\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:AdvancePreparationIcon}}\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 1989\n|PortionCalories = 99\n|DatePublished=14th October 2012\n|Author=Chef\n|Servings = Servings: 20 - Too much for my small mould!\n |Difficulty = 3\n |ImageComment = Stripy-shirt Cheddar\n |TotalTime = 6 hours\n |PrepTime = 6 hours plus maturation period\n |CookTime = None\n|Image = [[Image:Home-made Cheddar cheese recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\"><span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">So rewarding!</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">5</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">Making this gave me a real feeling of accomplishment!  Amazing.</span>\n \n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:TheJudge|The Judge]] </span></span>\n}}\nThis turned out to be quite successful homemade cheese recipe, though it was eaten before it matured properly!\n\nUse a [[double-boiler]] or you will scald the [[Milk|milk]] and spoil the taste of the [[Cheese|cheese]].  See here for [[ideas on how to improvise one]].\n\nIt is vital that you don't exceed any of the stated temperatures or your [[Cheese|cheese]] '''will''' fail.\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 7 [[Pints|pints]] full-cream [[Milk|milk]]\n| &frac14; teaspoon freeze dried [[DVI starter]]\n|* ''I used a generic [[Ascott]] starter''.\n| 8 drops [[Rennet|rennet]]\n| 1 tablespoon [[Sea Salt|sea salt]]\n\n}}\n\n===[[Mise en place]]===\n* [[Sterilise]] all equipment\n\n===Method===\n\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Warm the [[Milk|milk]] to 32\u00b0 C (90\u00b0 F)\n| Mix &frac14; teaspoons of [[freeze dried DVI starter]] with 4 tablespoons of lukewarm water.\n| Whisk into the [[Milk|milk]] and stir really well so it is properly mixed.\n| Cover and leave for 1 hour.\n| Mix 8 drops of [[Rennet|rennet]] with 4 tablespoons lukewarm water and whisk into the [[Milk|milk]]. Stir really well so it is properly mixed.\n| Leave for 2 hours for the [[Milk|milk]] to solidify.\n| [[Cut the curds]] with a long knife into 5 mm (1/4\") cubes.\n| Leave to rest for 20 minutes.\n| In a [[double boiler]], heat the outer water to 39\u00b0 C (102\u00b0 F), using extra heat to keep this temperature stable, and stir the [[Curds|curds]] regularly until they reach 39\u00b0 C (102\u00b0 F).  Stir regularly and don't overheat or the curds will melt together and you'll end up with [[Mozzarella cheese|mozzarella cheese]]!\n| Once the [[Curd|curd]] temperature is stable at 39\u00b0 C (102\u00b0 F), cook the [[Curds|curds]] for another 45 minutes. As before, stabilise by using a little extra heat - you won't need much. Stir regularly to prevent the curds knitting together.  A spring-type whisk (pictured) works well for this.\n| Drain the [[Curds|curds]] in a [[cheesecloth]] lined [[Colander|colander]].\n| Add them back to the [[double boiler]], stir well with a whisk to break up the [[Curds|curds]] and cook for another 45 minutes at 39\u00b0 C (102\u00b0 F).\n| Sprinkle in the [[sea salt]] and mix well.\n| Place the [[Curds|curds]] in a [[cheesecloth]] lined [[cheese mould]] and press with a 9kg (20 lbs) weight for 45 minutes.\n| Take the [[Cheese|cheese]] out of the [[cheese mould]] and turn it round.\n| Press it again with 22 kg (50 lb) for 24 hours.\n| Remove from the [[cheese press]] and dry for 5 days at room temperature.\n| Wrap in a sterilised [[cheesecloth]], seal the [[Cheddar]] with a [[flour]] and water paste and mature for 3 to 24 months\n| Unless you have a cave handy, the [[fridge]] is probably the best place to mature your [[homemade cheese]] although it's really going to be too cold. After discovering the top shelf of my often-opened fridge could be as much as 5\u00b0 C warmer than the bottom, I've decided to mature my cheeses there.  As all fridges differ, check various areas of your fridge with a thermometer to find the area that is around 11\u00b0C [51\u00b0 F], the ideal 'cave' temperature.\n|Ideally hard cheeses should be left to mature for up to 3 months or more and turned regularly; however, if you don't have the patience to wait that long for your home-made cheese you will find the results of a young cheese perfectly acceptable.\n}}\n<gallery widths=300px heights=300px perrow=5>\nImage:Cheddar-second-cooking.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Cooking the curds, second stage\nImage:Improvised-double-boiler-fo.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Improvised double boiler\n</gallery>\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes|Cheddar]]\n[[Category:Cheese making|Cheddar]]\n[[Category:Cheese recipes|Cheddar]]\n[[Category:British recipes|Cheddar]]\n[[Category:Snacks and light bites|Cheddar]]\n[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Cheddar]]\n\n[[Category:Uncooked]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#curds #cheesecloth #cheese #homemadecheddarcheese #cheesemould #doubleboiler #curd #cheddar #flour #dvistarter #cutthecurds </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }
    }
}

title": "Home-made cumin cheese",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Home-made cumin cheese a cheese recipe \n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#curds #cheese #cheesecloth #cuminseeds #doubleboiler #cheesemould #homemadecumincheese #cheesepress #colander #ascott #flour \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=This recipe for cumin flavoured Cheddar-type cheese is basically the same recipe as for Home-made Cheddar cheese apart from the flavouring. Use a\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{AdvancePreparationIcon}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 1701\n|PortionCalories = 85\n|DatePublished=31st October 2012\n|Author=Chef\n|Servings = Servings: 20 - Too much for my small mould!\n |Difficulty = 3\n |ImageComment = Stripy-shirt Cheddar\n |TotalTime = 6 hours, 30 minutes\n |PrepTime = 6 hours plus maturation period\n |CookTime = 30 minutes\n |Image = [[Image:Home-made Cheddar cheese recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Strange, but nice</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">4.7</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">Home-made cheese is such fun and so rewarding.  It's also a lot easier than you would think.</span>\n \n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:TheJudge|The Judge]] </span></span>\n}} \nThis recipe for cumin flavoured Cheddar-type [[cheese]] is basically the same recipe as for [[Home-made Cheddar cheese]] apart from the flavouring.\n\nUse a [[double-boiler]] or you will scald the [[Milk|milk]] and spoil the taste of the [[Cheese|cheese]].  See here for [[ideas on how to improvise one]].\n\nIt is vital that you don't exceed any of the stated temperatures or your [[Cheese|cheese]] '''will''' fail.\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 3.4 litres (6 pints) full-cream [[Milk|milk]]\n| &frac14; teaspoon freeze dried [[DVI starter]]\n|* ''I used a generic [[Ascott]] starter''.\n| 8 drops [[Rennet|rennet]]\n| 1.25 tablespoons of [[Sea Salt|sea salt]] (Noirmoutier sea salt \"Hot Spices\" [curry, cumin, chillies, mint]) \n| 1.5 teaspoons of [[dry-roasted]] [[cumin seeds]].\n\n}}\n\n===[[Mise en place]]===\n* [[Sterilise]] all equipment\n<gallery widths=300px heights=300px perrow=5>\nImage:Cumin-Cheddar-second-cooking.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Cooking the curds, second stage\nImage:Improvised-double-boiler-fo.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Improvised double boiler\n</gallery>\n===Method===\n\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Warm the [[Milk|milk]] to 32\u00b0 C (90\u00b0 F)\n| Mix &frac14; teaspoons of [[freeze dried DVI starter]] with 4 tablespoons of lukewarm water.\n| Whisk into the [[Milk|milk]] and stir really well so it is properly mixed.\n| Cover and leave for 1 hour.\n| Mix 8 drops of [[Rennet|rennet]] with 4 tablespoons lukewarm water and whisk into the [[Milk|milk]]. Stir really well so it is properly mixed.\n| Leave for 2 hours for the [[Milk|milk]] to solidify.\n| [[Cut the curds]] with a long knife into 5 mm (1/4\") cubes.\n| Leave to rest for 20 minutes.\n| In a [[double boiler]], heat the outer water to 39\u00b0 C (102\u00b0 F), using extra heat to keep this temperature stable, and stir the [[Curds|curds]] regularly until they reach 39\u00b0 C (102\u00b0 F).  Stir regularly and don't overheat or the curds will melt together and you'll end up with [[Mozzarella cheese|mozzarella cheese]]!\n| Once the [[Curd|curd]] temperature is stable at 39\u00b0 C (102\u00b0 F), cook the [[Curds|curds]] for another 45 minutes. As before, stabilise by using a little extra heat - you won't need much. Stir regularly to prevent the curds knitting together.  A spring-type whisk (pictured) works well for this.\n| Drain the [[Curds|curds]] in a [[cheesecloth]] lined [[Colander|colander]].\n| Add them back to the [[double boiler]], add the [[sea salt]] and [[cumin seeds]] and stir well with a whisk to break up the [[Curds|curds]] and cook for another 45 minutes at 39\u00b0 C (102\u00b0 F).\n| Hang the curds in a [[cheesecloth]] for 1 hour to drain.\n| Place the [[Curds|curds]] in a [[cheesecloth]] lined [[cheese mould]] and press at 9kg (20 lbs) for 45 minutes.\n| Take the [[Cheese|cheese]] out of the [[cheese mould]] and turn it round.\n| Press it again at 22 kg (50 lb) for 24 hours.\n| Remove from the [[cheese press]] and dry  for 5 days at room temperature.\n| Wrap in a sterilised [[cheesecloth]], seal the [[Cheddar]] with a [[flour]] and water paste and mature for 3 to 24 months\n| Unless you have a cave handy, the [[fridge]] is probably the best place to mature your [[homemade cheese]] although it's really going to be too cold. After discovering the top shelf of my often-opened fridge could be as much as 5\u00b0 C warmer than the bottom, I've decided to mature my cheeses there.  As all fridges differ, check various areas of your fridge with a thermometer to find the area that is around 11\u00b0C [51\u00b0 F], the ideal 'cave' temperature.\n}}\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes|Cumin]]\n[[Category:Cheese making|Cumin]]\n[[Category:Cheese recipes|Cumin]]\n[[Category:British recipes|Cumin]]\n[[Category:Snacks and light bites|Cumin]]\n[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Cumin]]\n[[Category:Boiled or simmered]]\n[[Category:Unusual recipes]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#curds #cheese #cheesecloth #cuminseeds #doubleboiler #cheesemould #homemadecumincheese #cheesepress #colander #ascott #flour </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]

title": "Home-made Derby cheese",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Home-made Derby cheese recipe Cheese making\n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#curd #cheesecloth #cheese #degrees #homemadederbycheese #whey #calciumchloride #liquidstarter #mould #brine #pasteurised \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=Traditionally, this cheese is made with 50% evening milk and 50% morning milk\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 2001\n|PortionCalories = 125\n|DatePublished=4th October 2012\n|Author = JuliaBalbilla\n|Servings = Servings: 16 - 1 cheese, 82 x 82 x 90 mm\n |Difficulty = 3\n |TotalTime = 4 hours plus pressing and maturation period\n |PrepTime = 4 hours\n |CookTime = None\n|Image = [[Image:Home-made Derby cheese recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Home-made cheese is divine</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">4.8</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">There is no better feeling than eating cheese you have made yourself.  This was divine! (we don't have a dairy either, so used normal milk.)</span> \n\n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:PSmith|Paul&nbsp;R&nbsp;Smith]] </span></span>\n}}\nTraditionally, this [[Cheese|cheese]] is made with 50% evening [[Milk|milk]] and 50% morning milk.  However, not having my own [[Cows|cows]], this is not possible, and unless you live near a farm that is registered to supply [[Unpasteurised|unpasteurised]] milk, probably not for you either.  This version is made with [[Pasteurised|pasteurised]] shop bought milk.\n\nThe quantity given will fit a small [[Ascott]] hard [[Cheese mould|cheese mould]] measuring 82 x 82 x 90 mm.\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 4 [[Litres|litres]] [[Pasteurised|pasteurised]] full-fat [[Milk|milk]]\n| A small pinch of [[DVI]] or 2 ml [[Liquid starter|liquid starter]]\n| 1.5 ml [[Calcium Chloride|calcium chloride]], mixed with a little cooled, [[Boiled|boiled]] water\n| 1.5 ml [[Rennet|rennet]] (animal or vegetarian), mixed with a little cooled, [[Boiled|boiled]] water\n| [[Salt]]\n| [[Brine]], made with 180 ml [[Salt|salt]] [12 level tablespoons] per 1 litre of water\n\n}}\n\n===[[Mise en place]]===\n* [[Sterilise]] all equipment\n===Method===\n\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Heat the [[Milk|milk]] slowly, using a [[Double boiler|double boiler]] until it has reach a temperature of 29 [[Degrees|degrees]] C.\n| Stir in the [[DVI]] or [[Liquid starter|liquid starter]] and leave for 15 minutes.\n| Add the [[Calcium Chloride|calcium chloride]] and stir throughly.\n| Stir in the [[Rennet|rennet]], stir and leave in a warm place for 45-60 minutes, until set.\n| [[Cut the curds]] into 1.2 cm cubes and slowly heat, stirring until the temperature reaches 36 [[Degrees|degrees]].  This should take 15 minutes.\n| Allow to settle for 15 minutes.\n| Drain off as much of the [[Whey|whey]] as you can and transfer the [[Curds|curds]] to a piece of [[Cheesecloth|cheesecloth]].\n| Tie the cloth at the top and tighten every 15 minutes for one hour as the [[Whey|whey]] drains.  A sterilised plastic clothes peg is useful for this.\n| Take the [[Curd|curd]] from the cloth and cut the curd into 4 strips.\n| Stack the strips on top of each other and cover.\n| After 30 minutes, put the inner [[Curd|curd]] strips on the outside and leave for another 30 minutes.\n| You then need to [[Dry-salt|dry-salt]], so weigh the [[Curd|curd]], cut it into [[Pea|pea]] sized pieces. \n| Add the [[Salt|salt]].  If you have a kilo of [[Curd|curd]], add 14g of salt, or for 500g curd add 7g.  You will need to work this out accurately depending on your exact weight!\n| Mix well.\n| Line your [[Mould|mould]] with clean [[Cheesecloth|cheesecloth]] (although personally, I did not actually line mine).\n| Press lightly for 1 hour and then increase the pressure a little for each hour afterwards.\n| Then leave under full pressure for 24 hours.\n| Remove the [[Cheese|cheese]] from the [[Mould|mould]], turn, and replace in a clean [[Cheesecloth|cheesecloth]].\n| Press under maximum pressure for a further two days.\n| Briefly place the [[Cheese|cheese]] in [[Brine|brine]] (for about and hour), then seal in water at 66 [[Degrees|degrees]] C for one minute.\n| Allow to dry, paint with [[rapeseed oil]] and wrap in a bandage until mature - about 2 months.\n| Unless you have a cave handy, the [[fridge]] is probably the best place to mature your [[homemade cheese]] although it's really going to be too cold. After discovering the top shelf of my often-opened fridge could be as much as 5\u00b0 C warmer than the bottom, I've decided to mature my cheeses there.  As all fridges differ, check various areas of your fridge with a thermometer to find the area that is around 11\u00b0C [51\u00b0 F], the ideal 'cave' temperature.\n}}\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes|Derby cheese]]\n[[Category:Cheese making|Derby cheese]]\n[[Category:British recipes|Derby cheese]]\n[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Derby cheese]]\n\n[[Category:Uncooked]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#curd #cheesecloth #cheese #degrees #homemadederbycheese #whey #calciumchloride #liquidstarter #mould #brine #pasteurised </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }
    }
}

title": "Home-made Stilton-type cheese",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Home-made Stilton-type cheese a cheese recipe\n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#curds #homemadestiltontypecheese #whey #dvistarter #penicilliumroqueforti #penicilliumroquefortii #pasteurised #homemadecheese #fridge #stilton #sticheltoncheese \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=Remember, you need to prepare the freeze dried Penicillium Roquefortii 24 hours in advance of making the cheese\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{Template:AdvancePreparationIcon}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 11520\n|PortionCalories = 576\n|DatePublished=22nd October 2012\n|Author=Chef\n|ImageComment = OK, I couldn't wait 3 months. This was incredible after 1 month!\n |Servings = Servings: 20 - Makes about 1 kg of [[Stilton]]-type [[Cheese|cheese]] - may reduce in weight slightly after maturing. \n |Difficulty = 3\n |TotalTime = 6 days\n |PrepTime = 6 days plus maturation period\n |CookTime = None\n|Image = [[Image:Home-made Stilton cheese.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Better than Roquefort</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">5</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">So pleased with this, it was better than stuff we bought in France!</span> \n\n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:PSmith|Paul&nbsp;R&nbsp;Smith]] </span></span>\n}}\n==Prepare 24 hours in advance!==\nRemember, you need to prepare the freeze dried [[Penicillium Roquefortii]] 24 hours in advance of making the cheese.  I always forget.\n\nA month or so on, and I can report this was an absolute success. Very creamy, almost runny, every bite seems to have a slightly different flavour. Totally recommended!\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 6 [[Litres|litres]] full cream milk (I used [[Pasteurised|pasteurised]], shop-bought milk)\n| A little [[DVI starter]] (see picture)\n| Freeze dried [[Penicillium Roquefortii]] (see picture)\n| 2 ml [[Rennet|rennet]]\n| Table salt (28g per 1200g of curd)\n}}\n\n===[[Mise en place]]===\n'''Prepare the [[Penicillium Roqueforti]] mould culture'''\n# [[Boil]] a little water and allow to go cold.\n# Pour 150 ml of the cold, [[Sterilised|sterilised]] water into a lidded container.\n# Whisk up a small amount of [[freeze dried Penicillium Roquefortii]] (see picture) into the cold, [[Boiled|boiled]] water so the powder is held in suspension.\n# Cover and [[Refrigerate|refrigerate]] for up to 24 hours - use within 3 days\n# [[Sterilise]] all equipment\n===Method===\n'''Setting the [[Curds|curds]]'''\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Using a [[Double boiler|double boiler]] pre-warmed to 29\u00b0C, add the cold [[Pasteurised|pasteurised]] [[Milk|milk]] and slowly bring the milk temperature to 29\u00b0C\n| Whisk  the [[DVI starter]] into a little of the warm [[Milk|milk]] and re-introduce the milk suspension into the boiler.\n| Pour the [[Penicillium Roquefortii mould culture]] into the warm [[Milk|milk]].  Whisk to mix. Cover with a clean [[Tea-towel|tea-towel]] and leave for 30 minutes.\n| Add 2ml of [[Rennet|rennet]] to 1 tablespoon of cold, previously [[Boiled|boiled]] water, mix well and add to the  [[Milk|milk]].\n| Whisk to mix, cover and leave in a warm place (about 22\u00b0C) until the curd sets.\n| Lay a boiled cheesecloth on a [[draining mat]] and then ladle all of the curds on to the cheesecloth.  The picture shows 3/4 of the curds - I had to put the rest into a second tray.\n| Fold to cover the curds and leave to stand in the [[whey]] for 60 minutes.\n| Wind one corner of the cheesecloth around the other three corners to make a Stilton knot (a kind of noose).\n| Hang the bag up to drain off the [[whey]].\n| Every 30 minutes for the next two hours, tighten the bag a little more.\n}}\n'''Salting and packing the curds'''\n{{RecipeMethod\n| After 2 hours, cut the [[curds]] into [[walnut]]-sized cubes.\n| Sprinkle the cubes evenly with table salt at a ratio of 28g per 1200g of curd.\n| Pack the [[curds]] into unlined moulds but don't compress them. (I used a colander as a mould for this batch)\n| Leave the [[curds]] for 5 days, turning daily to ensure it can still drain freely.  I stored mine in a the salad container in the fridge with a bowl of water in a vain attempt to maintain humidity.  Ideally a little warmer (cave-like) would be more ideal.\n| After 5 days, the cheese should have shrunk away from the sides of the mould.\n| Use a spatula to rub the surface of the cheese flat so there are no holes on the outside.\n| Cover with [[cling-film]] or rub with vegetable oil to seal the surface and leave to mature in a cool damp place.  Again, if you have a cave, that would be ideal!  Try to maintain a degree of humidity if possible.\n| After 5 days, remove the cling-film and create the airways for the veining to form by piercing the cheese at regular intervals with a sterilised knitting needle or kebab skewer.  (Take a close look at the high-resolution image of [[Stichelton cheese]] to see how the commercial cheese makers do this.)\n}}\nLeave to mature for as long as you can bear! A wooden or wicker plate is good for this as it won't make the cheese sweat. The ideal conditions are 8\u00b0C to 12\u00b0C at 90% humidity.\n\nUnless you have a cave handy, the [[fridge]] is probably the best place to mature your [[homemade cheese]] although it's really going to be too cold. After discovering the top shelf of my often-opened fridge could be as much as 5\u00b0 C warmer than the bottom, I've decided to mature my cheeses there.  As all fridges differ, check various areas of your fridge with a thermometer to find the area that is around 11\u00b0C [51\u00b0 F], the ideal 'cave' temperature. \n<gallery widths=300px heights=300px perrow=5>\nImage:Home-made Stilton-type cheese recipe.jpg|After 1 month, in its fridge 'cave'. On a cheese mat, atop a piece of wood, over a pool of water in the salad crisper.\nImage:Stilton packed.jpg|Packed in mould - leave 5 days\nImage:Salting the curds.jpg|Salting the curds\nImage:Draining the whey.jpg|Improvisation - draining the whey - step 9\nImage:Ladled.jpg|Ladled onto a cheese cloth, step 7 (about 3/4 of the total quantity)\nImage:Knife-tip.jpg|P.R. Knife-tip, used to treat 6 litres of milk (would probably do much more)\nImage:Knife-tip-DVI.jpg|DVI - Knife-tip, used to treat 6 litres of milk (would probably do much more)\n</gallery>\n===Variations===\nIf you wish to produce [[White Stilton]], follow the above recipe, just omit the [[Penicillium Roqueforti]] and ignore ther skewering stage.\n===Chef's notes===\nDon't worry about how much 'extra' water you add through the various stages because as soon as the cheese separates, it will just become part of the [[whey]] which is then of course discarded.\n\nThe original recipe used 4.5 litres of full-fat milk. I increased the amount to 6 litres. This produced about 1.2 kg of set curds at the packing stage.\n'''Temperature and humidity are very important'''.\n \nI have been known for a certain degree of impatience, not least when it comes to waiting for cheese to mature!  Well, after a week in wraps and a further week in the fridge at 8\u00b0C, sitting over a bowl of water in the salad crisper, I was most disappointed not to have a neatly veined piece of blue cheese. Pondering this dilemma on the hottest day of the year, I thought maybe a few days in a homemade humidifier, placed in our cool garage, might help things along a little.  The next morning when I scampered out to the garage to check progress, my pure white Stilton had overnight, turned into a huge blue furry football!  A quick check of my [[Minimum-maximum thermometer|minimum-maximum thermometer]] showed that it had got as warm as 22\u00b0C - far too warm, hence all the fur. \nRubbed clean of its blue fur coat, crumbled and re-constituted into a Stilton cylinder, it is back in the fridge and there it will stay for the next 3 months - caveat nibbler. \n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes|Stilton]]\n[[Category:Cheese recipes|Stilton]]\n[[Category:Cheese making|Stilton]]\n[[Category:British recipes|Stilton]]\n\n[[Category:Unusual recipes]]\n[[Category:Snacks and light bites|Stilton]]\n[[Category:Starters|Stilton]]\n[[Category:Vegetarian recipes|Stilton]]\n[[Category:Blue cheeses|Stilton]]\n[[Category:Uncooked]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#curds #homemadestiltontypecheese #whey #dvistarter #penicilliumroqueforti #penicilliumroquefortii #pasteurised #homemadecheese #fridge #stilton #sticheltoncheese </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }
    }

title": "Homemade shortcrust pastry",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Homemade shortcrust pastry, British recipe\n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#butter #pastry #homemadeshortcrustpastry #flour #icingsugar #foodprocessor #fridge #plainflour #mixer #cheese #fat \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=Whilst ready-made pastry is widely available, there may be times when you want to make your own\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 1809\n|PortionCalories = 452\n|DatePublished=2nd January 2013\n|Author = JuliaBalbilla\n|Servings = Serves 4 - Makes about 450 grams\n |Difficulty = 2\n |ImageComment = A ball of shortcrust pastry\n |TotalTime = 45 minutes\n |PrepTime = 45 minutes\n |CookTime = None\n |Image = [[Image:Homemade shortcrust pastry recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Nice</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">5</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">This was much easier than I thought at first.  Will do this again.</span>\n \n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:Klapaucius|Klapaucius]])</span></span>\n}}\nWhilst ready-made [[Pastry|pastry]] is widely available, there may be times when you want to make your own.  Ready-made pastry is [[Frozen|frozen]] and if you are in a hurry, it is quicker to make your own than wait for the frozen to [[de-frost]].\n\nMost ready-made [[Pastry|pastry]] will contain manufactured [[Fat|fat]], whereas you can choose your own fat type if you make it yourself.\n\nTraditionally, a mixture of half-[[Lard|lard]] and half-[[Butter|butter]] was considered the ideal mixture and it probably still is.  However, as a vegetarian, I always use 100% [[butter]].\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 250 g [[Plain flour|plain flour]], sifted\n| &frac14; teaspoon [[icing sugar]]\n| 6 g [[Salt|salt]]\n| 125 g cold [[Butter|butter]], cut into small chunks and chilled\n| About 75 ml iced water\n}}\n===Method===\n\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Mix the [[Flour|flour]] with the [[icing sugar]] and [[Salt|salt]] in a bowl and add the chunks of [[Butter|butter]].\n| If making the [[Pastry|pastry]] manually, cut the [[Butter|butter]] into the [[Flour|flour]] with cold scissors, until the mixture is like fine [[Breadcrumbs|breadcrumbs]].\n| To ensure that the [[Butter|butter]] has been sufficiently incorporated, shake the bowl back and forth.  Any large lumps will come to the surface and you can cut them in again.\n| Add the cold water, not all at once, stirring with a fork to mix it in.\n| Keep adding the water until you can form the mixture into a compact and non sticky ball, which will hold together.\n| Wrap in [[cling-film]] and place in the [[Fridge|fridge]] for half-an-hour before use.\n| This can be made in a [[Food processor|food processor]], in which case process the [[Flour|flour]], [[Salt|salt]] and [[Butter|butter]] together, using the pulse setting.  Slowly add the water and the mixture should automatically form itself into a ball when enough water has been added.  Do not over-process though, as it will make the mixture too warm.  A stand [[mixer]], if you have one, would be better than using a [[Food processor|food processor]].\n}}\n===Variations===\nYou can make additions to the [[Pastry|pastry]], eg. [[Spices|spices]], [[Cheese|cheese]] and [[Sugar|sugar]] (for a sweet pastry).  \n\n===Chef's notes===\nOnce the [[Pastry|pastry]] has rested in the [[Fridge|fridge]], roll it out according to your recipe's instructions and add the other ingredients.  However, I always put it back in the fridge at this stage for a further 30 minutes, before I put it into the preheated oven.  I do this even with ready-made [[pastry]].\n==See also==\n[[P\u00e2te bris\u00e9e]]'''\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes|Pastry shortcrust]]\n[[Category:Bread and baking|Pastry shortcrust]]\n[[Category:British recipes]]\n[[Category:Pies tarts and flans|Pastry shortcrust]]\n[[Category:Uncooked]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#butter #pastry #homemadeshortcrustpastry #flour #icingsugar #foodprocessor #fridge #plainflour #mixer #cheese #fat </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }
    }
}

title": "Homemade sweet shortcrust pastry",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Homemade sweet shortcrust pastry a British recipe\n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#butter #flour #icingsugar #fridge #egg #homemadesweetshortcrustpastry #breadcrumbs #lemonzest #pastry #desserts #foodprocessor \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=Ideal for sweet pies and desserts\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 1774\n|PortionCalories = 443\n|DatePublished=11th June 2012\n|Author=Chef\n|ImageComment = A ball of shortcrust pastry\n |Servings = Serves 4 - Makes 350 grams of pastry\n |Difficulty = 2\n |TotalTime = 20 minutes\n |PrepTime = 20 minutes\n |CookTime = None\n|Image = [[Image:Homemade shortcrust pastry recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\"><span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">\ud83e\udd67\ud83e\udd67\ud83e\udd67Perfect for apple pie</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">4</span>/5</span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">Perfect for apple pies</span>\n \n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\">[[User:Klapaucius|Klapaucius]] </span></span>\n}}\nIdeal for sweet pies and [[desserts]].\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 225 g [[Plain flour|plain flour]], sieved\n| 50 g [[icing sugar]]\n| 115 g cold [[Butter|butter]], cut into small chunks\n| Grated zest of 1 [[lemon]]\n| 1 large [[free range egg]], beaten\n| Splash of [[milk]]\n}}\n===Method===\n\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Sieve the [[flour]] from a height over a clean work surface\n| Repeat with the [[icing sugar]]\n| Rub the [[Butter|butter]] into the [[Flour|flour]] with cold hand, using the tips of your fingers, until the mixture is like [[Breadcrumbs|breadcrumbs]].\n| Add your [[lemon zest]] or any other flavouring you may be using\n| Now add the [[egg]] and a tiny splash of [[milk]] and combine until you have a ball of dough. Don't overwork the pastry here of you won't get a crumbly pastry\n| Keep adding the [[milk ]]until you can form the mixture into a ball, which will hold together, but not be sticky\n| Wrap in [[cling-film]] and place in the [[Fridge|fridge]] for half-an-hour before use.\n| This can be made in a [[Food processor|food processor]], in which case process the [[Flour|flour]], [[Sugar|sugar]], [[egg]] and [[Butter|butter]] together, using the pulse setting.  Slowly add the milk and the mixture should automatically form itself into a ball when enough milk has been added.  Do not over-process though, as it will make the mixture too warm.\n}}\n===Chef's notes===\nOnce the [[Pastry|pastry]] has rested in the [[Fridge|fridge]], roll it out according to your recipe's instructions and add the other ingredients.  However, I always put it back in the fridge at this stage for a further 30 minutes, before I put it into the preheated oven.  I do this even with ready-made pastry.\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes|Pastry shortcrust]]\n[[Category:Bread and baking|Pastry shortcrust]]\n[[Category:British recipes|Pastry shortcrust]]\n[[Category:Pies tarts and flans|Pastry shortcrust]]\n[[Category:Historic recipes]]\n\n[[Category:Uncooked]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#butter #flour #icingsugar #fridge #egg #homemadesweetshortcrustpastry #breadcrumbs #lemonzest #pastry #desserts #foodprocessor </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }
    }

title": "Honeyed Sausages with Soy Dipping Sauce",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",

                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Honeyed Sausages with Soy Dipping Sauce recipe\n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#glutenfree #honey #sausages #honeyedsausageswithsoydippingsauce #sausage #darksoysauce #recipesfromothersites #coriander #diced #sauce #roast \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=Yorkshire pork with a taste of the East; this combination makes a fabulous snack or tapas!  for the sauce  for the sausages\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 1003\n|PortionCalories = 167\n|DatePublished=18th October 2015\n|Author=Chef\n|ImageComment = \n|Servings = Serves 6\n|Difficulty = 1\n|TotalTime =  30 minutes\n|PrepTime =  10 minutes\n|CookTime =  20 minutes\n|Image = [[Image:Honeyed Sausages with Soy Dipping Sauce recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Not keen on the sauysages</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">2.5</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">But I liked the dip</span>\n \n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:TheJudge|The Judge]] </span></span>\n}}\nYorkshire [[Pork|pork]] with a taste of the East; this combination makes a fabulous [[Snack|snack]] or [[Tapas|tapas]]!\n{{RecipeIngredients\n\n}}\n====for the sauce====\n{{RecipeIngredientsNB\n| 1 [[Red chilli|red chilli]], deseeded and finely [[Diced|diced]]\n| A handful of fresh [[Coriander|coriander]], finely chopped\n| 1 tablespoon Rowse [[Chinese]] [[Honey]]\n| 1 tablespoon [[Dark soy sauce|dark soy sauce]] ([[Gluten free|gluten free]])\n| 1 tablespoon [[Light soy sauce|light soy sauce]] ([[Gluten free|gluten free]])\n| 1 teaspoon [[Sesame seed|sesame seed]] [[Oil|oil]] ([[Gluten free|gluten free]])\n| 2 [[Limes|limes]], [[Juice|juice]] only\n}}\n====for the sausages====\n{{RecipeIngredientsNB\n| 1 pack debbie&andrew's Harrogate 97% [[Sausages]], each [[Sausage|sausage]] cut in half [[On the diagonal|on the diagonal]]\n| 2 tablespoons [[Honey|honey]]\n| 4tbsp water\n}}\n\n===[[Mise en place]]===\nPreheat your oven to 200\u00b0 C (400\u00b0 F - gas 6), [fan oven 180\u00b0 C & reduce cooking time by 10 mins per hour]\n===Method===\n{{RecipeMethod\n\n| To make the [[Sauce|sauce]], mix all the ingredients together and put to one side in a pretty serving bowl.\n| Lay the halved [[Sausages|sausages]] in a single layer in the bottom of a [[Roasting tin|roasting tin]] and pour over the [[Honey|honey]] and water.\n| [[Roast]] in the preheated [[Oven|oven]] for 15 to 20 minutes, turning or shaking a couple of times.\n| When the [[Sausages|sausages]] are sticky and [[Browned|browned]] all over, [[Pile|pile]] into a bowl and serve alongside the [[Dip|dip]].\n}}\n[[Category:Recipes]]\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:British title": "Honey and Mustard Dressing",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Honey and Mustard Dressing recipe. title": "Honey cooked pork tenderloin (SV)",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Honey cooked pork tenderloin (cooked Sous vide) recipe\n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#pork #vegetables #carrots #orange #honey #swede #fivespice #butter #parsley #porktenderloin #chinese \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=Pork tenderloin marinated in honey and cooked Sous-sous-vide served with root vegetables\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 1774\n|PortionCalories = 887\n|DatePublished=25th May 2015\n|Author=Chef\n|ImageComment = Lamb tenderloin fillet\n|Servings = Serves 2\n|Difficulty = 2\n|TotalTime =  4-5 hours, 20 minutes (including marinating)\n|PrepTime =  1 hour, 20 minutes (including marinating)\n|CookTime =  3-4 hours\n|Image = [[Image:Lamb tenderloin fillet.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\"> <span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Pretty good</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">3</span>/5</span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">Not sure about the swede though - nasty things \ud83d\ude1c</span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:Sue_spins|Susie]] </span></span>\n}}\n[[Pork tenderloin]] [[Marinated|marinated]] in [[Honey|honey]] and cooked [[Sous-vide|sous-vide]] served with [[Root vegetables|root vegetables]]\n{{RecipeIngredients\n\n| 180g [[Carrots|carrots]], peeled and cut into batons\n| 150g piece of [[Swede|swede]], peeled and cubed\n| A large knob of [[Butter|butter]]\n| 2 x 225g pieces of [[Pork tenderloin|pork tenderloin]]\n| 30ml clear [[Honey|honey]]\n| 30ml cold pressed [[Rapeseed oil|rapeseed oil]]\n| [[Grated]] [[Zest|zest]] of half an [[Orange|orange]]\n| A pinch [[Chinese]] [[Five spice|five spice]]\n| [[Salt]] and [[Pepper|pepper]]\n| [[Italian]] [[Parsley|parsley]], finely chopped\n}}\n===[[Mise en place]]===\n\n* Pre-heat the water bath to 84\u00b0C (''183\u00b0F'')\n\n===Method===\n{{RecipeMethod\n\n| Place the [[Carrots|carrots]], [[Swede|swede]] and [[Butter|butter]] in a vacuum bag.\n| Season and seal.\n| Add to the water bath and cook for 1\u00bd hours.\n| Meanwhile, mix the [[Honey|honey]], [[Oil|oil]], [[Orange zest|orange zest]], [[Chinese]] [[Five spice|five spice]] and seasoning in a bowl.\n| Add the [[Pork|pork]] and coat with the [[Marinade|marinade]] on all sides.\n| Cover and place in the [[Fridge|fridge]] for at least 1 hour.\n| Place in a vacuum bag and seal.\n| Once the cooking time is up for the [[Vegetables|vegetables]], reduce the water bath temperature to 56.5\u00b0C (''134\u00b0F'') (for medium rare) or 60\u00b0C (''140\u00b0F'') (for medium).\n| Add the [[Pork|pork]] to the bath, leaving the pouch containing the [[Vegetables|vegetables]] where they are, and cook for 1\u00bd-2\u00bd hours.\n| Pre-heat to high, a pan containing a little [[Oil|oil]].\n| Remove the pouches from the water bath.\n| Open and drain the one containing the [[Pork|pork]] and [[Sear|sear]] for about 30 seconds on each side.\n| Cut the [[Pork|pork]] into slices and serve with the drained [[Vegetables|vegetables]].\n| Sprinkle the [[Vegetables|vegetables]] with the chopped [[Parsley|parsley]]\n}}\n===Serving suggestions===\nServe with [[Mustard sauce 2 (TM)|mustard sauce]]\n===Recipe source===\n\n* Adapted from a recipe by Chris Holland and Gary Woolliscroft\n===Variations===\nVary the combination of vegetables, but bear in mind that the [[pork]] is [[orange]] scented, so [[beetroot]] and [[carrots]] would go best.  You could replace the [[orange]] with [[herbs]].\n\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes|Pork tenderloin honey]]\n[[Category:British recipes|Pork tenderloin honey]]\n[[Category:Main courses|Pork tenderloin honey]]\n[[Category:Meat recipes|Pork tenderloin honey]]\n[[Category:Pork recipes|Pork tenderloin honey]]\n[[Category:Molecular gastronomy recipes|Pork tenderloin honey]]\n[[Category:Sous vide recipes|Pork tenderloin honey]]\n[[Category:Sous vide cooking|Pork tenderloin honey]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#pork #vegetables #carrots #orange #honey #swede #fivespice #butter #parsley #porktenderloin #chinese </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }
    }

title": "Honey Lime Fruit Salad",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Honey Lime Fruit Salad recipe \ud83c\udf6f\ud83c\udf4b\ud83e\udd57\n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#fruit #honeylimefruitsalad #salad #honey #juice #cashews #basilleaves #pears #images #freshginger #zest \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=A refreshing fruit salad with an Asian twist. Boot your 5 a day with this tasty recipe\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 1230\n|PortionCalories = 307\n|DatePublished=16th August 2014\n|Author=Chef\n|ImageComment = \n|Servings = Serves 4\n|Difficulty = 2\n|TotalTime =  15 minutes\n|PrepTime =  10 minutes\n|CookTime =  5 minutes\n|Image = [[Image:Honey Lime Fruit Salad recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Heavenly match</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">5</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">Sweet and sour salad. \ud83c\udf6f\ud83c\udf4b\ud83e\udd57</span> \n\n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:PSmith|Paul&nbsp;R&nbsp;Smith]] </span></span>\n}}\nThis takes [[Fruit|fruit]] [[Salad|salad]] to the next level. Incredible, zingy, Asian-inspired flavours for something a bit more impressive than your run-of-the-mill [[Fruit|fruit]] [[Salad|salad]], and it only takes ten minutes to make.\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n\n| 5 handfuls of a selection of [[Fruit|fruit]] (opt for 3-4 different varieties if possible)\n| 2 tablespoons [[Honey|honey]]\n| 2 teaspoons [[Fresh ginger|fresh ginger]] root, finely chopped or [[Grated|grated]]\n| 1 [[Lime|lime]], [[Zest|zest]] and [[Juice|juice]]\n| A few fresh [[Basil leaves|basil leaves]] (optional)\n| A large handful of [[Cashews|cashews]], toasted\n}}\n\n===Method===\n{{RecipeMethod\n\n| Cut your [[Fruit|fruit]] into bite-sized bits: Thinly slice your [[Pears|pears]], [[Apples|apples]] or [[Plums|plums]]. Segment those [[Oranges|oranges]]. Pit your [[Cherries|cherries]]. De-stalk [[Strawberries|strawberries]]. (You get the idea.)\n| Toss everything in a bowl, or arrange them prettily on a plate.\n| Gently warm the [[Honey|honey]] in a saucepan. Take off the heat. Swirl the [[Ginger|ginger]] through. Grate in some [[Lime zest|lime zest]]. Add a good squeeze of [[Juice|juice]].\n| Drizzle the mix over the [[Fruit|fruit]]. Scatter [[Cashews|cashews]] over the top. Finish with a little fresh [[Basil|basil]], if you wish. Pudding ready.\n}}\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes]]\n[[Category:British recipes]]\n[[Category:Snacks and light bites]]\n[[Category:Sweets and desserts]]\n[[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]\n[[Category:Fruit recipes]]\n[[Category:Abel and Cole veg box recipes]]\n[[Category:Uncooked]]\n{{Template:Abel and Cole veg box recipes attribution}}\n[[Category:Recipes from other sites]]\n[[Category:Unusual recipes]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#fruit #honeylimefruitsalad #salad #honey #juice #cashews #basilleaves #pears #images #freshginger #zest </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }

title": "Honey Pear Flapjacks",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Honey Pear Flapjack recipe \n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#pear #seeds #honey #grated #mixedspice #brownsugar #butter #banana #granulatedsugar #greaseproofpaper #unsaltedbutter \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=Think flapjack is not quite sticky enough? Pear and honey make all the difference. \n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 1846\n|PortionCalories = 153\n|DatePublished=16th August 2014\n|Author=Chef\n|ImageComment = \n|Servings = Serves 12\n|Difficulty = 2\n|TotalTime =  45 minutes\n|PrepTime =  15 minutes\n|CookTime =  30 minutes\n|Image = [[Image:Honey Pear Flapjacks recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Mum used to make these</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">5</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">Once a month my mum would make these as a treat.</span> \n\n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:PSmith|Paul&nbsp;R&nbsp;Smith]] </span></span>\n}}\nThink flapjack isn't quite sticky enough? [[Pear]] and [[Honey|honey]] do the trick. No [[Pear|pear]] to spare? Swap for the same weight of [[Grated|grated]] [[Apple|apple]] or mushed up [[Banana|banana]].\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n\n| 125g [[Unsalted butter|unsalted butter]] ''see Chef's notes below''\n| 125g [[Brown sugar|brown sugar]] ''see Chef's notes below''\n| 75g [[Honey|honey]]\n| 1 teaspoon [[Vanilla extract|vanilla extract]] or [[Seeds|seeds]] from \u00bd [[Vanilla pod|vanilla pod]]\n| 1 [[Lemon|lemon]], [[Zest|zest]] only (optional)\n| 200g [[Porridge oats|porridge oats]]\n| 1 teaspoon [[Mixed spice|mixed spice]]\n| A pinch of [[Sea Salt|sea salt]]\n| 200g [[pecan nuts]] (whole or chopped) and/or [[Seeds|seeds]]\n| 150g coarsely [[Grated|grated]] [[Pear|pear]]\n}}\n===[[Mise en place]]===\n\n* Preheat the [[Oven|oven]] to 160\u00b0 C (325\u00b0 F - gas 3), [fan [[Oven|oven]] 140\u00b0 C & reduce cooking time by 10 mins per hour]\n\n===Method===\n{{RecipeMethod\n\n| Line a 20cm square tin (or something of a similar size) with [[Greaseproof paper|greaseproof paper]] or [[Bake-O-Glide]]. It makes getting the flapjacks out the tin much easier.\n| Melt the [[Butter|butter]], [[Sugar|sugar]], [[Honey|honey]], [[Vanilla|vanilla]] and [[Lemon zest|lemon zest]] (if using) a saucepan till the [[Sugar|sugar]] dissolves.\n| Mix the [[Oats|oats]], [[Mixed spice|mixed spice]], a good pinch of [[Sea Salt|sea salt]] and the [[Nuts|nuts]]/[[Seeds|seeds]]. Fold the [[Grated|grated]] [[Pear|pear]] through.\n| Stir the melted [[Butter|butter]] mix through the [[Oat|oat]] mix till sticky and thick.\n| Press the mix into your prepared tin. Place in the centre of the middle shelf. [[Bake]] for 30 mins or till the flapjacks are golden on the top and crispy around the edges.\n| For best results, allow them to cool fully before cutting into them: tricky, but worth the wait.\n}}\n===Chef's notes===\n*[[Vegan]]? Use [[Coconut oil|coconut oil]] instead. It'll give the flapjacks a softer consistency but it's delicious nonetheless.\n\n*No [[Brown sugar|brown sugar]]? Use caster or [[Granulated sugar|granulated sugar]] instead. The texture will be slightly softer but they\u0092ll still taste superb.\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes]]\n[[Category:British recipes]]\n[[Category:Bread and baking]]\n[[Category:Historic recipes]]\n[[Category:Snacks and light bites]]\n[[Category:Sweets and desserts]]\n[[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]\n[[Category:Grain and bean recipes]]\n[[Category:Abel and Cole veg box recipes]]\n[[Category:Baked or roasted]]\n{{Template:Abel and Cole veg box recipes attribution}}\n[[Category:Recipes from other sites]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#pear #seeds #honey #grated #mixedspice #brownsugar #butter #banana #granulatedsugar #greaseproofpaper #unsaltedbutter </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }
    }
}

                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Horseradish dip\n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#horseradishdip #yogurt #horseradishroot #horseradishsauce #horseradishdip #limejuice #dip #dipsandsauces #gratedhorseradish #beefsauce\n|hashtagrev=12032020\n|description=This horseradish dip can be made as strong as you like, but I find if it contains too much horseradish it is difficult and not pleasant.\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|DatePublished=23rd October 2020\n|Author=Chef\n|ImageComment = \n|Servings = Serves 2\n|Difficulty = 1\n|TotalTime =  15 minutes\n|PrepTime =  15 minutes\n|CookTime = None\n|TotalCalories = 45\n|PortionCalories = 22 \n|Image = [[Image:Fresh horseradish dip.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Makes me sneeze!</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">4.7</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">Really tasty, love it but it makes my nose go funny!</span>\n \n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:TheJudge|The Judge]] </span></span>\n}}\nThis [[Horseradish|horseradish]] [[Dip|dip]] can be made as strong as you like, but I find if it contains too much horseradish it is difficult and almost unpleasant to eat.\n\nFive tablespoons of [[Yogurt|yogurt]] to an inch of [[Grated|grated]] [[Frozen|frozen]] [[Horseradish root|horseradish root]] was perfect. The root is quite thin, about the size of a big [[Fat|fat]] cigar.\n\nThis was great for dipping [[twice fried, air fried potato chips]].\n\n<gallery widths=300px heights=300px perrow=5>\nImage:Cleaned_and_dried_horseradish_root_pieces.jpg|Cleaned and trimmed horseradish root pieces from our dyke\nImage:Grate the horseradish.jpg|Coarsely grated horsradish root\n</gallery>\n{{RecipeIngredients\n\n| 5 tablespoons of [[Greek-style yogurt]]\n| 1 inch (2.5 cm) of [[Horseradish root|horseradish root]]\n| 1 teaspoon [[Lime juice|lime juice]]\n| Pinch of [[Sea Salt|sea salt]]\n}}\n\n===Method===\n{{RecipeMethod\n\n| Add the [[Yogurt|yogurt]] to a serving bowl\n| Grate the [[Horseradish root|horseradish root]] into the [[Yogurt|yogurt]]\n| Stir in the [[Lime juice|lime juice]] and [[Salt|salt]] and mix well.\n| Leave for 10 minutes, or longer, then give it a final mix and serve.\n}}\n===Variations===\nA little chopped fresh [[Parsley|parsley]] can add a little colour without overpowering the [[Dip|dip]].\n{{Template:HorseradishSeeAlso}}\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes]]\n[[Category:British recipes]]\n[[Category:Accompaniments]]\n[[Category:Dips and sauces]]\n[[Category:Snacks and light bites]]\n[[Category:Spicy recipes]]\n[[Category:Tapas, mezze and antipasti]]\n[[Category:Vegan recipes]]\n[[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]\n[[Category:Salad recipes]]\n[[Category:Vegetable recipes]]\n[[Category:Unusual recipes]]\n[[Category:Uncooked]]\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:12032020'>#horseradishdip #yogurt #horseradishroot #horseradishsauce #horseradishdip #limejuice #dip #dipsandsauces #gratedhorseradish #beefsauce #grated</code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"

title": "Horseradish pickle",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Horseradish pickle, British recipe \n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#horseradish #vinegar #horseradishpickle #salted #miseenplace #grating #onions #grated #pickle #horseradishsauce #whitewinevinegar \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=A hot pickle that can be used on its own or drained and used to make horseradish sauce. As the picture shows, grating horseradish can be worse than\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 385\n|PortionCalories = 11\n|DatePublished=24th December 2012\n|Author=Chef\n|ImageComment = Grinding horseradish- at \"The Pickle Guys\", New York City\n |Servings = Servings: 33 - 1 Jar\n |Difficulty = 1\n |TotalTime = 15 minutes\n |PrepTime = 15 minutes\n |CookTime = None\n|Image = [[Image:Grinding horseradish.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\"> <span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Yow!</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">4.8</span>/5</span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">My lips are still burning!</span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:Klapaucius|Klapaucius]] </span></span>\n}}\n\nA hot [[Pickle|pickle]] that can be used on its own or drained and used to make [[Horseradish sauce|horseradish sauce]].\n\nAs the picture shows, [[Grating|grating]] [[Horseradish|horseradish]] can be worse than slicing [[Onions|onions]], so be prepared!\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 300g [[Grated]] [[Horseradish|horseradish]] root\n| 284 ml [[White wine vinegar]]\n| Cooking [[Salt|salt]]\n\n}}\n\n===[[Mise en place]]===\n* Mix 1 teaspoon of [[Salt|salt]] to every 284 ml (&frac12; pint) of [[Vinegar|vinegar]]\n===Method===\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Peel and grate the [[Horseradish|horseradish]] root and loosely pack into small jars\n| Cover with the [[Salted|salted]] [[Vinegar|vinegar]]\n| Seal with [[Vinegar|vinegar]]-proof lids\n| Store in a cool place until needed\n}}\n===Chef's notes===\nUse [[frozen horseradish]] or freshly dug [[Horseradish|horseradish]] roots as they lose their flavour and pungency very quickly after pulling and cutting\n{{Template:HorseradishSeeAlso}}\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes]]\n[[Category:Accompaniments]]\n[[Category:British recipes]]\n[[Category:Dips and sauces]]\n[[Category:Marinades dressings and butters]]\n[[Category:Pickles and preserves]]\n[[Category:Spicy recipes]]\n[[Category:Vegan recipes]]\n[[Category:Vegetable recipes]]\n[[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]\n[[Category:Pickled]]\n[[Category:Uncooked]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#horseradish #vinegar #horseradishpickle #salted #miseenplace #grating #onions #grated #pickle #horseradishsauce #whitewinevinegar </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"

title": "Hot mint and caper sauce",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Hot mint and caper sauce, British recipe \n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#hotmintandcapersauce #mint #roasting #gravy #lamb #flour #chicken #capers #stock #garlic #sauce \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=I saw Jamie Oliver do this on his Jamie at home series\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 369\n|PortionCalories = 61\n|DatePublished=31st October 2012\n|Author=Chef\n|ImageComment = Mint and capers, ready to chop.\n|Servings = 6\n|Difficulty = 2\n|TotalTime = 10 minutes\n|PrepTime = 5 minutes\n|CookTime = 5 minutes\n|Image = [[Image:Hot mint and caper sauce recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Perfect with lamb</span>''<span style=\"line-height:180%\">\n\n<span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">5</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">The capers make this for me.</span>\n \n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:TheJudge|The Judge]] </span></span>\n}}\nI saw Jamie Oliver do this on his ''Jamie at home series''. It's a wonderful accompaniment for [[lamb]], but does rely very heavily on using the juices from [[roasting]] the [[lamb]], so do bear this in mind.  You can follow the Hot Mint and Caper Sauce recipe, it's part of [[Jamie Oliver's 4 hour slow roast lamb]] or you can use the directions here.\n\n\n'''For the hot [[caper]] and [[Mint|mint]] [[Sauce|sauce]]'''\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 1 tablespoon plain [[Flour|flour]]\n| 2 big handfuls of picked [[Mint|mint]] leaves\n| 4 tablespoons [[Capers|capers]]\n| 1 pint of [[Chicken|chicken]] [[Stock|stock]]\n| 2 tablespoons [[Sherry|sherry]] [[Vinegar|vinegar]]\n| 2 Whole garlic cloves, unpeeled and roasted with the joint, optional\n}}\n===Method===\n\n\n'''Hot mint and caper sauce'''\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Hopefully you will have a baking tray with lovely caramelised juices from the aftermath of [[roasting]].\n| Heat the [[roasting tray]] on the [[hob]] and add a tablespoon of plain [[Flour|flour]] and stir well to soak up all of the lovely juices.\n| Roughly chop the [[Mint|mint]] leaves and the [[Capers|capers]] and add to the [[Roasting|roasting]] tray.\n| If you have roasted garlic, squeeze a few of the [[Garlic|garlic]] cloves into the [[gravy]].\n| Add the [[Chicken|chicken]] [[Stock|stock]] to the tray, stirring well to thicken, but don't cook it for ages.\n| Add a final splash of [[Sherry vinegar]] to the [[gravy]], stir and serve hot.\n}}\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes]]\n[[Category:Accompaniments]]\n[[Category:Dips and sauces]]\n[[Category:Historic recipes]]\n[[Category:Pickles and preserves]]\n[[Category:British recipes]]\n[[Category:Boiled or simmered]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#hotmintandcapersauce #mint #roasting #gravy #lamb #flour #chicken #capers #stock #garlic #sauce </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }

title": "Hot water crust pastry",
                "revisions": [
                    {
                        "contentformat": "text/x-wiki",
                        "contentmodel": "wikitext",
                        "*": "<!-- seo -->\n{{#seo:\n|title=Hot water crust pastry, British recipe \n|titlemode=replace\n|keywords=#flour #hotwatercrustpastry #eggyolk #lard #pork #boil #bake #miseenplace #dough #plainflour #shortening \n|hashtagrev=032020\n|description=Hot water crust is a type of pastry used for savoury pies, such as pork pies, game pies, etc. Hot water crust was traditionally used for making hand-\n}}\n<!-- /seo -->\n\n{{Template:CookTools}}\n{{recipesummary\n|TotalCalories = 1584\n|PortionCalories = 264\n|DatePublished=6th July 2013\n|Author=Chef\n|Servings = Serves 6 - Enough pastry for 6 small [[pork]] pies\n|Difficulty = 2\n|ImageComment = Hand raised pork pie made with hot water crust pastry\n|TotalTime = 1 hour 15 minutes\n|PrepTime = 20 minutes\n|CookTime = 55 minutes\n|Image = [[Image:Hand raised pork pie with hot water crust pastry recipe.jpg|alt=Electus]]\n<span class=\"review\">\n<span class=\"reviewHeader\">\n====Best recipe review====\n</span>\n''<span class=\"reviewTitle\">Tasty, but not healthy!</span>''\n\n<span style=\"line-height:180%\"><span style=\"font-size:180%;\"><span class=\"reviewScore\">3.5</span>/5 </span>\n\n<span class=\"reviewDesc\">Yummy pie pastry but not very good for you with all that fat.  Now and again for a special treat!</span> \n\n<span class=\"reviewAuthor\"> [[User:PSmith|Paul&nbsp;R&nbsp;Smith]] </span></span>\n}}\nHot water crust is a type of pastry used for savoury pies, such as [[pork]] pies, game pies, etc. Hot water crust was traditionally used for making hand-raised pies.\n\nAs the name suggests, the pastry is made by heating water, melting the [[fat]] in this, bringing to the [[boil]], and finally mixing with the [[flour]]. This can be done by either beating the [[flour]] into the mixture in the pan, or by kneading on a pastry board. Either way, the result is a hot and rather sticky paste that can be used for hand-raising - shaping by hand, sometimes using a dish or bowl as an inner mould. As the crust cools, its shape is largely retained, and it is filled and covered with a crust, ready for [[baking]]. Hand-raised hot water crust pastry does not produce a neat and uniform finish, as there will be sagging during the cooking of the filled pie. This is generally accepted as the mark of a hand-made pie. It is possible, however, to [[bake]] the pastry in a mould, as with other pies.\n\nRaised pies are easier to make whilst the pastry is warm.\n\n'''There is a recipe for [[Melton Mowbray style pork pies|Melton Mowbray style pork pies here]].'''\n\n{{RecipeIngredients\n| 225 g (8 oz) strong [[plain flour]]\n| Pinch of crushed [[sea salt]]\n| 25 ml (25 g) (1 fl oz) [[milk]]\n| 25 ml (25 g) (1 fl oz) water\n| 75 g (3 oz) [[lard]] or [[shortening]]\n| 1 large [[egg yolk]], whisked, for glazing and sealing\n}}\n\n===[[Mise en place]]===\n* Preheat the oven to 180\u00b0 C (350\u00b0 F - Gas 4)\n\n===Method===\n\n{{RecipeMethod\n| Sift the [[salt]] and [[flour]] into a bowl\n| Mix the water and [[milk]] into a medium-sided pan and heat gently\n| Cut the [[lard]] into small pieces and drop into the [[milk]]/water mix\n| Once the [[lard]] has completely melted, raise the heat and bring to the [[boil]] and then immediately remove from the heat\n| Pour into the [[flour]] and, using a wooden spoon, mix well\n| Dust a chopping board with a little extra [[flour]] and [[Kneading bread|knead]] the [[dough]] for a minute or two\n| Two thirds of the dough for the pies and 1/3 for the lids\n| Divide the larger piece into 6 and roll into balls and, using your hands, mould each ball into a pie shape (an upturned glass is useful for this)\n| ''Fill the pies with your desired filling''\n| Using a pastry [[brush]], paint a little of the [[egg yolk]] around the rim of each pie\n| Divide the remaining third into six pieces, roll into balls and then roll each ball flat to make the pie lids\n| Crimp the lids to the pies with the tines of a fork and glaze the pies with any remaining [[egg yolk]]\n| Make a little slash or hole in the top of each pie to allow [[steam]] to escape and [[bake]] on a tray for about 50 to 55 minutes\n| Allow to cool on a wire rack\n}}\n===Serving suggestions===\n\nServe warm or cold\n\n===Chef's notes===\n\nHaving made these, I would suggest that this quantity is better suited to 4 slightly larger pies.  Although unconventional, to prevent them collapsing, I would bake them in [[muffin trays]].\n\n===See also===\n\n* Macaroni pie (Scottish)\n* [[Melton Mowbray style pork pies|Melton Mowbray style pork pie]]\n\n{{RecipeLine}}\n[[Category:Recipes]]\n[[Category:Historic recipes]]\n[[Category:Pork recipes]]\n[[Category:Pies tarts and flans]]\n[[Category:British recipes]]\n[[Category:Baked or roasted]]\n\n<!-- footer hashtags --><code 'hashtagrev:032020'>#flour #hotwatercrustpastry #eggyolk #lard #pork #boil #bake #miseenplace #dough #plainflour #shortening </code><!-- /footer_hashtags -->"
                    }
                ]
            }
        }
    }
}
